data.name: [The Wizard Book Lectures: 1A] Hero's Square Root
data.description: This kata is based on the video lecture [1A: Overview and Introduction to Lisp](https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-001-structure-and-interpretation-of-computer-programs-spring-2005/video-lectures/1a-overview-and-introduction-to-lisp/). More information on the "Wizard Book" series at the bottom of the description. --- # Hero's Square Root The Greek mathematician and engineer [Hero of Alexandria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hero_of_Alexandria) (also known as "Heron") contributed, among other things, this [method for approximating a square root](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Methods_of_computing_square_roots#Babylonian_method): For some number *n*, to approximate its square root: 1. Begin with some arbitrary positive number *g* (for "guess"). 2. Take the average of *g* and *n/g*. The result will be closer to the square root. 3. Continue taking successive averages, updating the guess until *g* and *a/g* are within some acceptable margin of error. # Implementation Strategy Part of the learning objectives here are abstraction and composition. As such, you will be tasked with implementing a number of small composable pieces. Your language probably has libraries or built-in standard functions for some of these pieces, but take the time to implement them yourself. *(Note: Exact function names will vary by language, but will be provided.)* - `square` Given a number, return its square. - `average` Given two numbers, return their average. - `abs` (Absolute Value) Given a number, return its absolute value. - `improve` Given a number *g* and a target number *n*, based on Hero's method above, return a number closer to *√n* than *g*. - `good-enough?` Given a number *g* and a target number *n*, return true if *g2* is within ±0.001 of *n*. - `try` Given an initial number *g* and a target number *n*, return a number whose square is within ±0.001 of *n*. - `sqrt` (Square Root) Given a number *n*, return a number whose square is within ±0.001 of *n*. # Notes on Accuracy For the level of accuracy, we'll target a square root that, when squared, is within 0.001 of the target number. Some examples: - For a square root of 4, given that 2.0002 * 2.0002 is about 4.0008, we could accept 2.0002 as a square root. - For a square root of 4, given that 2.00025 * 2.00025 is about 4.001, we would reject 2.00025 as a square root. --- ### About the "Wizard Book" The 1984 book [***Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs***](https://mitpress.mit.edu/sites/default/files/sicp/index.html) (Also known as the ***Wizard Book*** or its acronym ***SICP***), by Hal Abelson, Gerald Jay Sussman, and Julie Sussman, remains highly influential in the fields of software engineering, computer science, programming language design, and hacker culture in general. ### Video Series This Kata series is based on MIT Open Courseware video lectures which can be viewed for free here: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-001-structure-and-interpretation-of-computer-programs-spring-2005/video-lectures/ While following along with the video lectures is not necessary to complete the Katas, it's highly recommended.
